audio_caption: The audio begins with a distinct chime sound. Then, a female speaker introduces a channel and mentions Wendy Williams criticizing Meghan Markle's emotional interview, adding that this made her "give Wendy the side eye." She states the interview was taken from Meghan and Prince Harry's documentary, "Harry and Meghan: An African Journey." This is followed by music.

The audio begins with a woman reporting that Meghan Markle opened up about dealing with stress from British tabloids, spoken in a standard news reporting style. This is followed by a woman recounting a conversation with her British friends, who warned her that the tabloids would destroy her life, expressed in a conversational tone. She then reveals her initial naive reaction to the warning. A dramatic sound effect quickly concludes the clip.

The clip begins with a female speaker discussing the vulnerability of women, especially during pregnancy, and the challenges this creates, followed by the difficulties of being a new mother or newlywed. Her tone is reflective and candid. She then expresses gratitude for being asked how she's doing, noting that not many people have inquired, emphasizing the real struggles happening behind the scenes. A male voice chimes in, summing up her sentiment as "not really okay" and acknowledging it has been "really been a struggle". The female speaker then confirms with one word: "yes." Throughout the clip, an underlying gentle musical score adds a somewhat somber mood.

The audio clip begins with a female speaker expressing sympathy for "Meghan," stating that "this was very sad to watch." The speaker believes that "Meghan has been under a lot of pressure ever since she married into the Royal Family." Her tone is empathetic and conversational.

The clip begins with a single female speaker discussing Meghan Markle's life changes after marrying Prince Harry. She speaks with a concerned tone, focusing on the pressures Meghan faces, the tabloid harassment, and her relationship with her father. The speaker emphasizes the stress Meghan experiences as a new mother, wife, and member of the Royal Family. There is no music or significant background noise during the speech, keeping the focus on the speaker and her message.

The audio begins with a female speaker discussing Wendy Williams's perspective on Meghan Markle's problems, noting that Williams "doesn't seem to care all that much" and "said she does not feel sorry for her." Another female voice begins to speak more animatedly about Meghan Markle, remarking that she was warned not to marry Prince Harry, but that "some hating ass girlfriend" cautioned her against it. The speaker questions the logic of friends advising against marrying a prince, implying Meghan may be lying to gain sympathy. This speaker then discusses an interview Meghan gave while standing the whole time, remarking, "this is kind of awkward." Laughter is briefly audible. Then, the speaker mocks the initial statement that the first speaker made. Lastly, the speaker applauds Markle's "plotation on the royal situation", but asks her not to "garner sympathy from us," characterizing her friend as a hater who should be dismissed. She concludes by saying there is "something about her." Background music is minimal, contributing a subtle, consistent hum.

The audio clip starts with a female speaker stating, "and you know what," then addressing someone as "girl, um, Meghan." There is a slight pause followed by a second female speaker saying, "Meghan, don't be surprised that the paparazzi are everywhere." She adds that this is "because you're now a royal" and notes that they weren't followed when she was on *Suits*, stating, "we didn't even know who you are." Both speakers are using a conversational tone, and there's no audible background music or environmental sounds.

The audio clip starts with two female speakers discussing an anecdote about someone wanting to be a runway model at Wendy's. The first speaker speaks with slight bemusement and excitement. The second speaker joins in, mentioning someone wanting to be an "expert." The first speaker urges her on, and the second speaker continues, explaining how "Meghan Markle from Suits" contacted their talent department expressing interest in fashion and runway opportunities. The first speaker adds a "right" and a "tell it". The second speaker continues explaining the story. She ends her anecdote by noting that by the time they decided to book her, she was already engaged. The first speaker concludes with a blunt remark directed at Meghan Markle, adding "nobody feels sorry for you". The audio clip ends with an audience cheering, signaling the end of a performance or story.

The clip begins with a female speaker questioning Wendy's apparent lack of sympathy, given her own experiences in the public eye and interviews where she broke down and cried. This segues into audio from a separate source featuring a male interviewer and a female interviewee. The female speaker expresses her emotional state, claiming that she has lived a full life and endured two somethings. The male interviewer acknowledges her statement. Another female speaks up, seemingly upset and explaining that this was unplanned but accepting of the situation. This segment transitions to another female speaker stating the intention to change their last name, then another woman's protest that her name is Wendy Hunter and that she doesn't want her son's name taken away from her. The emotional intensity increases as the speaker begins to cry. Finally, a separate, calm voice says, "Next."

The audio clip features one female speaker passionately discussing the emotional challenges faced by a woman named Wendy, describing her experiences with divorce and infidelity. The speaker expresses sympathy, but then criticizes Wendy's lack of empathy towards another woman. The speakerâ€™s tone shifts from sympathetic to critical. Fading out, the female speaker leaves a cliffhanger.

The audio clip begins with a single female speaker expressing well wishes for Meghan Markle, acknowledging the challenges she faces within the Royal Family and media scrutiny, drawing a parallel with Princess Diana. Her tone is empathetic and concerned. She then transitions the conversation to a new topic.

The audio clip begins with one female speaker discussing Megan Thee Stallion's recent Instagram spat with her makeup artist. The speaker explains that the makeup artist was upset he wasn't credited after Megan posted a video from her Vogue interview talking about learning to do makeup. The speaker continues, reporting that the makeup artist commented "Makeup by Akilah Face," Megan responded "and me," and the makeup artist clapped back clarifying his role versus Megan's in the makeup process. The speaker notes that the makeup artist felt some type of way and was ranting about it on his Instagram story.

The audio clip begins with a female speaker relaying information, apparently quoting someone who claims to have done someone's makeup, and that the subject of the makeup "touched up her eyebrows" and put on "her MAC powder on her face like she does every time." She continues with a statement that she does the subject's face, and states that "all artists should be paid and tagged," especially when talented, and that this is the "end of discussion." The speaker continues to describe that it seems petty and that the makeup artist made a "big deal out of nothing." According to the speaker, the person could have simply texted and stated how he felt, "instead of getting in his feelings about it." The speaker maintains a slightly exasperated tone throughout the clip.

The audio clip starts with a female speaker opining that someone "is not wrong for wanting to be acknowledged" to promote his business but should do so more professionally. She criticizes his pettiness in saying a woman only fills in her brows and uses a little powder, noting that in another post, he admitted that "Megan does help do her own makeup," quoting his post where he says they collaborate and sometimes he'll do all the makeup, sometimes she will, and sometimes they collaborate. In his words, he's grateful she chose him as "Makeup by Achilla Face and the Stallion". She concludes that he basically confirmed what Megan said, that "she definitely does help do her own makeup."

The audio clip starts with a female speaker expressing confusion about "the competitive energy between them" before discussing the skills and professionalism of a make-up artist, named "Akil LaFave" and a client, "Megan", then referencing social media etiquette. The tone is conversational and analytical. Then the speaker is quoting someone who likes "Akil a lot", saying "we get into it like every day". Another person responds with laughter. The speaker then asks what the listener thinks about Megan and Akil's situation. The audio concludes with a thank you and sign-off.
